Graphical abstract Ag-FeN x -N-C as a dual-functional electrocatalyst regulates electron-flow direction by Mott-Schottky effect and induces mass transfer through apically guiding channel for high-performance zinc-air batteries. The disparity in the transfer of carriers (electrons/mass) during the reaction in zinc-air batteries (ZABs) results in sluggish kinetics of the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER), along with elevated overpotentials, thereby imposing additional constraints on its utilization. Therefore, the pre-design and target-development of inexpensive, high-performance, and long-term stable bifunctional catalysts are urgently needed. In this work, an apically guiding dual-functional electrocatalyst (Ag-FeN x -N-C) was prepared, in which a hierarchical porous nitrogen-doped carbon with three-dimensional (3D) hollow star-shaped structure is used as a substrate and high-conductivity Ag nanoparticles are coupled with iron nitride (FeN x ) nanoparticles. Theoretical calculations indicate that the Mott-Schottky heterojunction as an inherent electric field comes from the two-phase bound of Ag and FeN x , of which electron accumulation in the FeN x phase region and electron depletion in the Ag phase region promote orientated-guiding charge migration. The effective modulation of local electronic structures felicitously reforms the d-band electron-group distribution, and intellectually tunes the mass-transfer reaction energy barriers for both ORR/OER. Additionally, the hollow star-shaped hierarchical porous structure provides an apical region for fast mass transfer. Experimental results show that the half-wave potential for ORR is 0.914 V, and the overpotential for OER is only 327 mV at 10 mA cm−2. A rechargeable ZAB with Ag-FeN x -N-C as the air cathode demonstrates long-term cycling performance exceeding 1500 cycles (500 h), with a power density of 180 mW cm−2. Moreover, when employing Ag-FeN x -N-C as the air cathode, flexible ZABs demonstrate a notable open-circuit voltage of 1.42 V and achieve a maximum power density of 65.6 mW cm−2. Ag-FeN x -N-C shows guiding electron/mass transfer route and apical reaction microenvironment for the electrocatalyst architecture in the exploration prospects of ZABs. Keywords Hollow star structure Mott-Schottky effect Apically guiding effect Bifunctional catalysis Zinc-air batteries 1 Introduction Given the growing energy demand of human society, it is of great significance to develop efficient energy conversion equipment [1,2]. The zinc-air batteries (ZABs) have become an attractive energy conversion device due to its abundant reserves, high safety, and high energy density. However, the slow four-proton-electron transfer kinetics and high overpotential of the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) limit the application of ZABs. Essentially, the imbalance of carrier electron/mass transfer reaction incurs the above issues [3,4]. Therefore, the development of cheap, high-performance, and long-term stable multifunctional catalysts is a pressing task for the future energy industry [5,6]. The adsorption energy of reaction intermediates (O*, OH*, and OOH*) serves as a crucial parameter in elucidating the catalytic activity depicted in volcano plots when exploring electrocatalysts for ORR [7]. From this perspective, compared to other noble metal materials, the element Ag not only occupies a relatively high position on the volcano graph but also possesses the cost-effective advantages (approximately one-fiftieth of Pt) and high conductivity. More importantly, Ag exhibits better electrochemical stability under alkaline conditions, unlike Fe, Co, and Ni, which are prone to oxidation or hydro-oxidation. However, due to its d10 electron structure, Ag has a weak oxygen binding energy (OBE), resulting in an activity being only one-tenth that of Pt [8,9]. So far, researchers have made many optimizations in morphology, loading methods, and forming alloys with other metals. For instance, Johnston et al. prepared Ag75Cu25 alloy nanocatalysts using vapor deposition to obtain superior catalytic activity, the enhanced ORR activity was attributed to a 0.12 eV increase in the d-band center compared to pure Ag [10]. However, the overall performance of silver catalysts in ORR still lags behind platinum-based catalysts. FeN x -C catalysts are considered one of the best alternatives to noble metal-based catalysts due to their excellent catalytic activity in ORR [11,12]. However, the relatively suboptimal carrier transfer rates (electron/mass) often result in excessive overpotential during catalytic reactions. In the electrochemical processes of ORR and OER, electron transfer and mass transfer occur simultaneously and are inseparable [13]. Generally, establishing a heterojunction structure is a key pathway to achieve rapid electron transfer. In recent years, the Mott-Schottky heterojunction formed by coupling metal conductors with semiconductor materials has gained widespread attention as a conceptual verification strategy. According to the Mott-Schottky effect, electron flow can occur spontaneously at the interface of a metal/semiconductor heterojunction until equilibrium is reached in terms of work function. This modulation at the interface continuously alters the work function of the Schottky barrier, modifies the electron cloud density of the catalyst, and leads to an accumulation of negative charges on the high work function side. The resulting electron donor-acceptor pair functions as an efficient catalyst, enhancing the ability of the surface metal to donate electrons toward the active site and providing a viable pathway for electron transfer to the adsorbed oxygen intermediate [14,15]. However, this concept design is rarely used in dual-functional oxygen electrocatalysis and rechargeable ZABs systems. Moreover, another critical factor in the electrochemical processes of ORR/OER is mass transfer. Promoting mass transfer can be achieved through two approaches. The first one involves the enhancement of effective collisions between reactants and active sites, while the second one entails the construction of well-designed mass diffusion pathways. About this proposed the three-dimensional (3D) hollow star-shaped configuration [16], previous studies indicate that the high curvature tips of the star-shaped design can augment the local electric field, positively influencing mass transfer [17,18], Additionally, the internal cavities within the hollow structure not only offer extra three-phase interfaces to promote the diffusion of reactants on the catalyst but also accelerate the reduction and evolution of O2. Based on the above analysis, constructing a dual-functional electrocatalyst with both rapid charge transfer (through the Mott-Schottky effect) and fast mass transfer (through an advanced structure) is essential. In this work, a nitrogen-doped carbon with a 3D hollow star-shaped structure was used as the substrate. High-conductivity Ag nanoparticles were coupled with iron nitride (FeN x ) nanoparticles to develop a dual-functional electrocatalyst (Ag-FeN x -N-C). The material exhibited a hollow-graded porous structure, providing ample three-phase reaction interfaces and rapid mass transfer channels for electrochemical processes. Additionally, owing to the inherent advantage of the material sharp tips, it presents shorter transport distances for reactants and reaction products compared to flat components. The Mott-Schottky interface formed between the Ag and FeN x phases generates an inherent electric field, leading to spontaneous rearrangement of energy bands and redistribution of charges. This resultant electron donor-acceptor pair acts as a highly efficient catalyst, augmenting the ability of the surface metal to donate electrons to the active site while providing a directed pathway for electron transfer towards adsorbed oxygen intermediates. The density functional theory (DFT) calculation reveals that the interaction between Ag and FeN x exerts precise control over the electronic structure of the catalyst, leading to a reduction in adsorption/desorption energy of reaction intermediates and a significant enhancement in electrocatalytic activity for both ORR/OER. Test results show 0.914 V of half-wave potential for ORR and 327 mV of overpotential for OER. The rechargeable ZABs prepared with Ag-FeN x -N-C as the air cathode demonstrate long-term cycling performance, showing promising prospects for commercial applications. 2 Results and discussion 2.1 Synthesis and structural characterizations The synthetic process of the hollow star-shaped Ag-FeN x -N-C electrocatalyst is illustrated in Fig. 1 . Initially, 2-methylimidazole (MelM), Zn (NO3)2·6H2O, and cetyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB) are dissolved in deionized water, and a star-shaped precursor ZIF is prepared through a simple chemical precipitation method. The growth mechanism of this star-shaped structure has been elucidated in previous studies [19,20]. Following that, dopamine hydrochloride (DA) is employed to coat the precursor ZIF, resulting in the formation of the coated star-shaped structure ZIF@PDA. Owing to a substantial presence of –OH and N functional groups, Fe3+ and Ag+ can readily be absorbed onto the surface of PDA chains through electrostatic attraction [21]. The ZIF@PDA@Ag+/Fe3+ material is then subjected to pyrolysis in a tube furnace under the argon atmosphere. The material is first carbonized at 600 °C for 2 h to form stable iron-nitrogen compounds. Subsequently, the temperature is further increased to 900 °C for an additional 2 h to evaporate the zinc species present in the material (the boiling point of zinc compared to carbon is relatively low being 907 °C). The carbonized material is denoted as Ag-FeN x -N-C. Similarly, carbonaceous materials Ag-N-C and FeN x -N-C are obtained by carbonizing the corresponding ZIF@PDA@Ag+ and ZIF@PDA@Fe3+ under similar reaction conditions. This strategy effectively prevents the aggregation of Fe and Ag metals and promotes the separation of Ag nanoparticles or iron-nitrogen compounds embedded in the porous carbon structure. The morphology of the material was characterized using scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM). Synthesized ZIF crystals exhibit a uniform star-shaped structure (Fig. 2 a–c and Fig. S1a), with an average particle size of around 800 nm. After carbonization, the resulting catalyst Ag-FeN x -N-C still retains the star-shaped structure (Fig. 2d–f and Fig. S1b), with a slight contraction in particle size to an average of around 700 nm. Additionally, the enlarged image of a single particle reveals its rough and wrinkled surface (Fig. 2f), which is attributed to the anisotropic thermal shrinkage of ZIF caused by the carbon shell derived from PDA [21]. Both before and after carbonization, the particles maintain high-curvature tips, which play a promoting role in subsequent electrocatalytic processes. SEM images of fractured particles indicate the hollow internal of the particles (Fig. 2g and Fig. S2), aligning well with the schematic diagram in Fig. 1. As seen from Fig. S3, the same series of materials all maintain a hollow star-shaped structure. The formation of this hollow structure is ascribed to the facile interfacial stress between ZIF and PDA during high-temperature pyrolysis [22,23]. Generally, a hollow structure is expected to accelerate mass and electron transfer during the reaction [24]. High-resolution TEM (HRTEM) images of the Ag-FeN x -N-C sample and corresponding lattice spacing profiles are shown in Fig. 2(h and i) and Fig. S4 The lattice stripes with a spacing of 0.236 and 0.204 nm respectively correspond to the (111) and (200) crystal planes of metallic Ag. Furthermore, the lattice stripe with a spacing of 0.208 nm corresponds to the (111) crystal plane of FeN0.0560, while the 0.202 nm of stripe is assigned to the (110) crystal plane of FeN0.0760 (Fig. S5). As seen from Fig. S6, Ag-FeN x -N-C possesses some obvious heterogeneous interfaces between the Ag phase and FeN x phase, indicating the formation of a Mott-Schottky Ag/FeN x phase nanostructure. Therefore, there is a lattice contact between metallic Ag and iron-nitrogen compounds, providing a realistic basis for subsequent electron transfer between Ag and Fe. Elemental mapping analysis of the Ag-FeN x -N-C sample reveals a uniform distribution of Fe, N, Ag, and C elements throughout the framework (Fig. 2j). Specifically, the uniformly distributed N element in the material indicates the widespread presence of ORR active sites (FeN x ) on the carbon support [25]. Additionally, the overlapping distribution of Ag and Fe elements in the shell of the particles also indicates lattice contact between metallic Ag and iron-nitrogen compounds. The preceding analysis demonstrates our successful creation of the Ag-FeN x -N-C catalyst with a 3D hollow star structure. The crystalline phases of the obtained catalyst were characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD) spectra (Fig. 3 a). The original peaks of the Ag-FeN x -N-C sample match well with Ag (PDF#87-0717), FeN0.0560 (PDF#75-2127), and FeN0.0760 (PDF#75-2137), indicating the formation of high-phase purity and crystallinity of metallic Ag and iron-nitrogen compounds in the carbon support. Similarly, the original peaks of the Ag-N-C sample match well with Ag (PDF#87-0717), and those peaks of the FeN x -N-C sample match well with FeN0.0560 (PDF#75-2127). In order to better understand the specific surface area and pore information of the sample, nitrogen adsorption-desorption measurements were conducted, and all series of samples exhibit type IV isotherms (Fig. 3b) with distinct hysteresis loops, indicating the coexistence of micropores and mesopores. Further analysis of the pore size distribution indicates the hierarchical pores (Fig. S7 and Table S1). The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area of Ag-FeN x -N-C is 593.52 m2 g−1, higher than that of Ag-N-C (382.56 m2 g−1) and FeN x -N-C (476.77 m2 g−1). Moreover, the average pore diameter and total pore volume of bimetallic-doped materials gradually increase compared to single-metal-doped ones. This suggests that the Ag-FeN x -N-C material after carbonization can achieve the maximum specific surface area and abundant hierarchical porous structure, accelerating mass transfer during the ORR/OER process [26,27]. All samples exhibit two typical peaks in the Raman spectra at 1302 cm−1 (D band) and 1547 cm−1 (G band) (Fig. 3c). The peak at 1302 cm−1 indicates the degree of graphitization of the material, while the peak at 1547 cm−1 represents structural defects in the carbon lattice. The I D/I G value of Ag-FeN x -N-C is the smallest compared to other samples, indicating a higher degree of graphitization and faster electron conductivity. The coexistence of defects and graphitic carbon synergistically enhances activity and conductivity during the catalytic process [28,29]. The surface composition of the synthesized materials was analyzed using X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) to analyze the chemical states and bonding types of the elements. The XPS spectra of Ag-FeN x -N-C show typical peaks for Fe, Ag, N, C, and O. The XPS spectra of FeN x -N-C exhibit characteristic peaks for Fe, O, C, and N. The XPS spectra of Ag-N-C display typical peaks for Ag, N, C, and O (Fig. S8 and Table S2). The C 1s spectra of the three samples reveal three characteristic peaks at 284.7 eV (C–C), 285.5 eV (C–N), and 288.7 eV (C=O/C=N) (Fig. 3d). These peaks exhibit features similar to highly graphitized carbon, confirming that the carbon-based substrate retains its basic electronic structure even after the introduction of iron or silver elements [30]. The presence of C–N indicates nitrogen doping in the carbon matrix, which can enhance the conductivity of the catalyst and its activity as a catalyst support [31]. The N 1s spectra of Ag-FeN x -N-C and FeN x -N-C can be deconvoluted into four different peaks: graphitic-N (401.23 eV), pyridinic-N (398.28 eV), pyrrolic-N (400.43 eV), and Fe–N (399.31 eV) [32]. In the case of Ag-N-C, where the silver element exists in elemental form, the N 1s spectrum can be deconvoluted into graphitic-N (401.23 eV), pyridinic-N (398.28 eV), and pyrrolic-N (400.43 eV) (Fig. 3e). It has been reported that pyridinic nitrogen replaces carbon atoms at the edges of graphite layers, and by providing lone pair electrons, it can enhance the onset potential of ORR, thereby promoting the activity of the carbon-based substrate [33]. Additionally, graphite-N can improve charge transfer rates and facilitate the adsorption of intermediates (*OOH and *OH) with pyridinic-N to accelerate ORR/OER [34]. Metal-N is generally considered to produce a Fe-N-C structure with single-atom Fe or Fe nanoclusters encapsulated in carbon layers, which is believed to be an effective active site for ORR [32]. Due to the relatively high proportion of active nitrogen atoms in the Ag-FeN x -N-C sample (Fig. 3f and Table S3), it exhibits excellent catalytic activity. 2.2 Mechanism analysis for enhanced electrochemical performance In order to gain a deeper understanding of the reaction mechanisms of the Ag-FeN x -N-C catalyst in alkaline electrolytes for both ORR and OER, an investigation into the electronic structure and valence states of materials within the same series was conducted. In solid-state band theory, the transfer behavior of electrons is closely related to the Fermi level (E F) and work function of the metal [35]. The work function values, equivalent to the work function (Φ) of the metal material [36], were determined by comparing the monomer ionization energy values of the samples (Ag-N-C and FeN x -N-C) using ultraviolet photoelectron spectroscopy (UPS) (Fig. 4 a). The results indicate that the work function of Ag-N-C is 5.28 eV, and the work function of FeN x -N-C is 5.59 eV. The E F difference between Ag-N-C and FeN x -N-C provides favorable conditions for the formation of the Mott-Schottky interface and the charge transfer in the Ag-FeN x -N-C sample. Additionally, XPS analysis was employed to compare the Ag 3d and Fe 2p spectra of Ag-N-C, FeN x -N-C, and Ag-FeN x -N-C samples, further elucidating the electron transfer processes between the Ag and FeN x phases. Fig. 4(c) shows the detailed XPS Ag 3d spectra of Ag-N-C and Ag-FeN x -N-C samples, fitted into two main peaks, Ag 3d 3/2 and Ag 3d 5/2 [37]. The fitted peak positions for Ag-N-C are 368.27 and 374.25 eV, while those for Ag-FeN x -N-C are 368.38 and 374.36 eV. This indicates that, compared to the Ag-N-C sample, the high-resolution XPS Ag 3d peaks in Ag-FeN x -N-C have shifted towards higher binding energies by 0.11 eV, suggesting a reduced electron cloud density in the Ag 3d orbitals. Fig. 4(b) displays the detailed XPS Fe 2p spectra of FeN x -N-C and Ag-FeN x -N-C samples [13]. These peaks correspond to the 2p 3/2 states of Fe2+ (710.81 eV), Fe3+ (714.19 eV), and Fe0 (707.74 eV), and the 2p 1/2 states of Fe2+ (720.14 eV), Fe3+ (724.17 eV), and Fe0 (717.56 eV). Notably, compared to the FeN x -N-C sample, the Fe 2p XPS spectra in Ag-FeN x -N-C have shifted towards lower binding energies by 0.71 eV, indicating an increased electron cloud density in the Fe 2p orbitals. Due to the reduced electron cloud density in Ag 3d and the increased electron cloud density in Fe 2p, electrons are induced to transfer from the Ag phase to the FeN x phase [38,39]. As mentioned earlier, the differential work functions of the Ag and FeN x phases meet the requirements for constructing Schottky barriers [40]. XPS results also indicate the possibility of charge transfer between the Ag and FeN x phases. Therefore, to better describe the interfacial interactions between the Ag and FeN x phases and precisely delineate electron transfer, we described the electron movement at the Ag/FeN x interface by establishing a Mott-Schottky structure model (Fig. 4d and e). In the FeN x phase, the doping of N atoms into the lattice of Fe results in the formation of a bandgap, influencing the work function, thereby lowering the maximum of the valence band (E V)and the bottom of the conduction band (E C). The Fermi level of metal Ag (E Fm) lies within the bandgap of FeN x , higher than the Fermi level of FeN x (E Fs). Arising from the imbalance of E F on both sides of the Mott-Schottky interface, the charge transfer from the Ag phase to the FeN x phase occurs, thereby achieving an equilibrium state where the E F on both sides is equal. As a result, electrons enrich on the FeN x side, forming a nucleophilic surface, which improves the adsorption of hydroxyl radicals and accelerates the kinetics of the oxygen evolution reaction as well as demonstrates superior oxygen evolution electrocatalytic activity. Holes will accumulate on the Ag phase side, forming a positively charged Ag surface, which enhances the adsorption of oxygen intermediates, thereby boosting the electrocatalytic activity for oxygen reduction (Fig. 4f) [41,42]. With the rectifying effect at the Mott-Schottky interface, Ag-FeN x -N-C enhances electron transfer capability and optimizes the adsorption-desorption energy barrier for oxygen intermediates at the reaction interface, thereby reducing the activation energy for a specific reaction step [43]. Consequently, this significantly improves the dual-functional catalytic performance of OER/ORR. In order to further understand the electron transfer process in the Ag-FeN x -N-C catalyst and the reasons for its outstanding activity as an ORR/OER catalyst, DFT calculations were conducted [44,45]. Based on the crystal structures of Ag and FeN x , three different nanomodels were proposed for FeN x -N-C, Ag-N-C, and Ag-FeN x -N-C (Figs. S9 and S10). To demonstrate the aforementioned electron redistribution, differential charge density analysis was conducted on the optimized Ag-FeN x -N-C model (Fig. 5 a). In this model, regions highlighted in yellow indicate electron enrichment, while electron loss processes are emphasized in green. It can be observed that there are significant and numerous electron transfer processes at the active sites of Ag-FeN x -N-C; specifically, electrons migrate from Ag to FeN x through the Mott-Schottky interface, resulting in a substantial local field effect. Through computational analysis (Fig. S11), the d-band center of the Ag-FeN x -N-C model (−2.15 eV) is situated between Ag-N-C (−3.95 eV) and FeN x -N-C (−1.97 eV). Ag-N-C and FeN x -N-C structures have weak and strong affinities, respectively, towards the intermediate *OH species, limiting their ORR capabilities. In Ag-FeN x -N-C, FeN x gains electrons from Ag, raising the Fermi level, reducing the d-band center, improving *OH species adsorption, and consequently enhancing ORR activity [46,47]. Meanwhile, we analyze the d-orbital before and after doping Ag nanoparticles with FeN x through projection density of states (PDOS) (Fig. 5c and d). In the FeN x -N-C catalyst, it is observed that the dxz and dyz orbitals exhibit significant asymmetry, as well as the partially filled orbitals in the d orbitals (Fig. 5d). However, upon introducing Ag nanoparticles to form a Mott-Schottky interface, the electron flow towards the FeN x phase leads to the reduction of the dxz and dyz orbitals. This further illustrates the decrease in the magnetic moment within the Projection Augmented Wave (PAW) sphere (Fig. 5c), optimizing the catalytic performance [48,49]. The ORR/OER reaction pathways in alkaline electrolytes involve four different reaction steps, primarily characterized by the adsorption and desorption mechanisms of *OH, *O, and *OOH intermediate species (Fig. S12) [50]. Fig. 5(e) describes the optimized structures and differential charge density distributions of these intermediates for the models in each reaction step. In the ORR process, the rate-determining step for FeN x -N-C, Ag-N-C, and Ag-FeN x -N-C models is identified as the *OH to H2O conversion step (Fig. 5b). However, the similarity in this rate-determining step arises for from different reasons. As indicated in Fig. 5(f) and Fig. S13(a and b), in the Ag-N-C model, there is minimal interaction between the p orbitals of various oxygen intermediates and the d orbitals of Ag, with electron clouds not intersecting. This results in a weak interaction of the active site Ag with various oxygen intermediates. Particularly, the adsorption capacity for *OH is weaker, leading to difficulties in *OH adsorption and consequently affecting the conversion to H2O [51]. In contrast, as shown in Fig. 5(f) and Fig. S13(c and d), the situation for FeN x -N-C is exactly the opposite of Ag-N-C. The p orbitals of various oxygen intermediates extensively interact with the d orbitals of Fe. After *OH adsorption, the electron cloud density of O p orbitals sharply decreases, indicating a strong bonding interaction between Fe and O. This demonstrates the high affinity of the active center Fe for *OH species, requiring an energy overcoming of 3.20 eV for the conversion to H2O. As shown in Fig. 5(f) and Fig. S14, in the Ag-FeN x -N-C model, due to the electron transfer between the Ag and FeN x phases, the spatial charge distribution at the interface is altered. This moderate interaction between O p orbitals and Ag, Fe d orbitals improves the adsorption capacity for various oxygen intermediates, particularly effectively regulating the adsorption capacity for *OH. Therefore, it has the minimum energy barrier compared to the reference sample in the rate-limiting step. In the OER process, the rate-determining steps for all three models involve the conversion of *O to *OOH (Fig. S15). As expected, introducing Ag nanoparticles into the FeN x -N-C system helps transform FeN x nanoparticles in Ag-FeN x -N-C samples into a negatively charged state, improving the adsorption of hydroxyl radicals and significantly enhancing OER activity, consistent with the results of the aforementioned d-band modulation [52,53]. These results further confirm the synergistic mechanism and regulation formed by the electronic transfer and Mott-Schottky catalyst, which can accelerate charge transfer and benefit the electrochemical performance of the catalyst interface. 2.3 Electrocatalytic performance In a KOH solution with a pH of 13, the ORR catalytic activity of all catalysts was evaluated using a standard three-electrode system, and all potentials were calibrated to the reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE) [54,55]. The cyclic voltammetry (CV) curves show a distinct reduction peak in an O2-saturated solution, while no corresponding peak appears in an N2-saturated solution (Fig. S16), indicating their electrochemical activity for ORR. Ag-FeN x -N-C exhibits a more positive oxidation peak (0.915 V) compared to other materials (including commercial Pt/C) suggesting its superior ORR activity. From Fig. 6 (a), it can be concluded that the linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) curve of the Ag-FeN x -N-C catalyst exhibits superior ORR catalytic activity, with a half-wave potential (E 1/2) of 0.914 V. Furthermore, the Tafel slope of Ag-FeN x -N-C (83.2 mV dec−1) is the lowest among all the materials (Fig. 6c), indicating that Ag-FeN x -N-C has a faster ORR reaction kinetics, which is comparable to or even better than recently reported catalysts (Table S4). Additionally, the kinetic current density (J K) reflecting intrinsic activity by excluding diffusion effects can be calculated from the LSV curves at 0.9 V (Fig. 6b) [56]. The results show that the J K value of Ag-FeN x -N-C at 0.9 V is the highest (13.3 mA cm−2), and it is 23.0 times the value of Pt/C (0.578 mA cm−2). In order to investigate the ORR reaction pathway of Ag-FeN x -N-C, LSV curves were studied at different rotation speeds within the range of 400–2500 r min−1 (Fig. 6d). The calculated electron transfer number (n) from the corresponding Koutecky-Levich plots is 3.93, indicating a preferred 4-electron reaction pathway. Furthermore, the rotating ring-disk electrode was applied to detect n and H2O2 yield [57]. In the ORR voltage range, the H2O2 yield remains below 1.05%, and the calculated n is 3.98 (Fig. 6e), further confirming that the obtained Ag-FeN x -N-C sample follows a 4-electron ORR reaction pathway, advantageous for achieving excellent long-term stability in ZABs [58]. To ensure catalyst stability, we conducted chronoamperometry tests at 0.5 V and 900 r min−1 (Fig. 6f). After testing for up to 60 h, the current of Ag-FeN x -N-C shows no significant decay, still maintaining 92% of the initial current, while commercial Pt/C experiences a noticeable decline to 57% of the initial current after 25 h. Additionally, Ag-FeN x -N-C exhibits good methanol tolerance (Fig. S17), with almost no decrease in current density upon methanol addition, while Pt/C shows a significant current decay. To achieve commercial applications in rechargeable zinc-air batteries, electrocatalysts must exhibit activity in both the ORR and the OER [59]. Therefore, in a KOH solution with a pH of 14, the OER catalytic activity of all catalysts was evaluated using a standard three-electrode system and all potentials were calibrated to the RHE. From the LSV curves (Fig. 7 a), it can be seen that the overpotential of the Ag-FeN x -N-C catalyst at 10 mA cm−2 (E j=10) is 327 mV, lower than Ag-N-C (385 mV) and FeN x -N-C (360 mV), while slightly trailing behind the commercial Ir/C (297 mV). This indicates excellent electrochemical activity. Correspondingly, the Ag-FeN x -N-C catalyst has a lower OER Tafel slope (65.6 mV dec−1) compared to Ag-N-C (118.3 mV dec−1) and FeN x -N-C (89.6 mV dec−1) (Fig. 7b and Table S5), indicating its fast OER catalytic reaction kinetics [60]. Moreover, a small electrochemical impedance can provide rapid proton transport capability [61]. In comparison, Ag-FeN x -N-C has a lower charge transfer resistance (Rct) of ∼33.5 Ω than the other samples in the same series and is roughly equivalent to Ir/C (Fig. 7c), suggesting that the introduction of Ag nanoparticles improves the conductivity of the catalyst. These results indicate that the built-in electric field formed by Ag nanoparticles and FeN x compounds effectively enhances the adsorption of hydroxyl radicals, thereby improving the catalytic activity of Fe-based catalysts for OER. Furthermore, the electrochemical activity was further studied through electrochemical double-layer capacitance measurements (Fig. 7d and Figs. S18 and S19). Ag-FeN x -N-C exhibits a larger active surface area, with a double-layer capacitance (C dl) of 9.34 mF cm−2, indicating its significant electrochemical catalytic potential. To test material stability, we performed CV cycle tests and chronoamperometry tests to verify the OER stability of the materials (Fig. 7e and Fig. S20). The LSV curves of Ag-FeN x -N-C before and after 5000 cycles of CV testing (0.5–0.7 V, 0.1 V s−1) almost completely overlap, and the current after 30 h of chronoamperometry testing only decays to 81.6% of the initial current. These results indicate that the Ag-FeN x -N-C material exhibits excellent OER stability. ΔE (the difference between E j=10 and E 1/2) is commonly used to evaluate the bifunctional activity of electrocatalysts [62,63]. As shown in Fig. 7(f), Ag-FeN x -N-C has the smallest potential gap (ΔE = 0.643 V), outperforming other samples and commercial Pt/C + Ir/C. These results suggest that the Ag-FeN x -N-C electrocatalyst possesses good reversible activity for ORR/OER. 2.4 Practical application To illustrate the potential application of Ag-FeN x -N-C as crucial electrode material in energy conversion devices, a homemade ZAB with a 6 M KOH electrolyte was constructed (Fig. 8 a). The ZABs assembled with the Ag-FeN x -N-C catalyst demonstrates an open-circuit voltage of 1.62 V (Fig. 8b) and a maximum power density of 180 mW cm−2 (Fig. 8c), both surpassing those of the ZABs assembled with a commercial Pt/C + Ir/C catalyst as the air cathode (1.58 V, 106 mW cm−2), comparable to or even better than recently reported catalysts (Table S6). Fig. 8(d) indicates that the Ag-FeN x -N-C material demonstrates significantly lower charging potentials and a smaller charge-discharge voltage gap across the entire current density range. Under a constant current discharge condition, the specific capacity of ZABs was normalized to the consumed zinc mass (Fig. 8e). The specific capacity of Ag-FeN x -N-C-based ZABs is 813 mA h g−1 and the energy density is 862 Wh kg−1, better than those of commercial Pt/C + Ir/C based ZABs (765 mA h g−1, 819 Wh kg−1). The constant current discharge curves are shown in Fig. 8(f), indicating a gradual decrease in the corresponding potentials with increasing current density. When the current density is restored to its initial value, the voltage of both assembled ZABs almost returns to its initial value. However, the output voltage of Ag-FeN x -N-C-based ZABs consistently exceeds that of commercial Pt/C + Ir/C-based ZABs, demonstrating superior rate performance and durability. Further, the charge-discharge cycling stability of Ag-FeN x -N-C-based ZABs under constant current was recorded (Fig. 8g). ZABs assembled with Ag-FeN x -N-C can cycle for over 1500 rounds, with an initial voltage gap of 0.93 V and energy efficiency of 54.7%. After continuous cycling for 1000 rounds, the energy efficiency remains at 59.6%, and the voltage gap is 0.83 V. As seen from Fig. S21, the structure of the material still maintains the hollow star-shaped morphology after long-term cycling, proving that the Ag-FeN x -N-C material has excellent cycling stability and structural stability in practical applications. Solid-state zinc-air batteries (sZABs) have garnered significant attention for applications in flexible and wearable devices. Here, we further assembled sZABs with polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) as the gel electrolyte and using Ag-FeN x -N-C as the electrode material (Fig. S22). The open-circuit voltage of the sZABs prepared with Ag-FeN x -N-C catalyst is 1.42 V (Fig. S23a and b), surpassing that of Pt/C + Ir/C-based sZABs (1.37 V). Additionally, its maximum power density is 65.6 mW cm−2, also exceeding that of Pt/C + Ir/C which is 23.6 mW cm−2. The cyclic stability of sZABs based on Ag-FeN x -N-C was assessed through repeated charge-discharge tests (Fig. S23c). Importantly, the sZABs based on Ag-FeN x -N-C demonstrate stable operation for over 2700 min without significant potential decay or efficiency loss. The utilization of air cathodes consisting of Ag-FeNx-N-C enables three sZABs to illuminate 4.5 V light emitting diode (LED) arrays (Fig. S24), thereby demonstrating their potential for various application scenarios. The experimental results indicate that, with the synergistic effects of edge effects and the Mott-Schottky interface, the Ag-FeN x -N-C material holds great promise for applications in rechargeable zinc-air batteries. 3 Conclusions In order to reinforce carrier (electron/mass) transfer reaction in ZABs, we have elaborately designed and successfully synthesized a dual-functional electrocatalyst with an Ag/FeN x Mott-Schottky heterojunction through a chemical precipitation-thermal decomposition method. The Mott-Schottky heterojunction formed between the Ag phase and the FeN x phase facilitates directional charge transfer at the interface by generating an inherent electric field. Localized electrophilic and nucleophilic regions optimize the d-band center of the catalyst and effectively tune the adsorption-desorption barriers for reaction intermediates, thereby synergistically enhancing the ORR/OER electrocatalytic performance. Additionally, the hollow star-shaped hierarchical porous structure provides apical three-phase reaction interfaces and rapid mass transfer pathways, significantly improving electron/mass transfer. Benefiting from the apically guiding electron/mass transfer reaction and interface modulation induced by Ag/FeN x Mott-Schottky effect, Ag-FeN x -N-C achieves fast reaction kinetics and exhibits outstanding dual-functional catalytic activity. The rechargeable ZABs based on Ag-FeN x -N-C exhibit excellent long-term cycling performance and high power density. Simultaneously, the sZABs show high open-circuit voltage and power density. The findings of this study present a viable prospect for the implementation of an apical guiding electrocatalyst in facilitating electron/mass transfer reactions of ZABs. coredata.dc:description: The disparity in the transfer of carriers (electrons/mass) during the reaction in zinc-air batteries (ZABs) results in sluggish kinetics of the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER), along with elevated overpotentials, thereby imposing additional constraints on its utilization. Therefore, the pre-design and target-development of inexpensive, high-performance, and long-term stable bifunctional catalysts are urgently needed. In this work, an apically guiding dual-functional electrocatalyst (Ag-FeN x -N-C) was prepared, in which a hierarchical porous nitrogen-doped carbon with three-dimensional (3D) hollow star-shaped structure is used as a substrate and high-conductivity Ag nanoparticles are coupled with iron nitride (FeN x ) nanoparticles. Theoretical calculations indicate that the Mott-Schottky heterojunction as an inherent electric field comes from the two-phase bound of Ag and FeN x , of which electron accumulation in the FeN x phase region and electron depletion in the Ag phase region promote orientated-guiding charge migration. The effective modulation of local electronic structures felicitously reforms the d-band electron-group distribution, and intellectually tunes the mass-transfer reaction energy barriers for both ORR/OER. Additionally, the hollow star-shaped hierarchical porous structure provides an apical region for fast mass transfer. Experimental results show that the half-wave potential for ORR is 0.914 V, and the overpotential for OER is only 327 mV at 10 mA cm−2. A rechargeable ZAB with Ag-FeN x -N-C as the air cathode demonstrates long-term cycling performance exceeding 1500 cycles (500 h), with a power density of 180 mW cm−2. Moreover, when employing Ag-FeN x -N-C as the air cathode, flexible ZABs demonstrate a notable open-circuit voltage of 1.42 V and achieve a maximum power density of 65.6 mW cm−2. Ag-FeN x -N-C shows guiding electron/mass transfer route and apical reaction microenvironment for the electrocatalyst architecture in the exploration prospects of ZABs.
